page.title: 01Local History
page.content: Rawcliffe Bridge is a small village (pop 600) situated some six miles from the port of Goole in the west of the county of Humberside. The surrounding area forms part of the Vale of York, is very flat and barely above sea level. Until the 17th. century the area was part of a vast marsh, but in 1626 a famous Dutch engineer, Cornelius Vermuyden reclaimed 24 000 acres by redirecting the River Don ten miles to the north and building a system of dykes to feed the new man made waterway. This river flows through Rawcliffe Bridge. As well as draining the land Vermuyden improved the soil quality by systematic flooding to create rich fertile 'warp' which is now high quality agricultural land.
